body: What does open data have the power to do?
displayTitle: Why does the physical activity sector need open data?
title: Why does the physical activity sector need open data?

_items.text: Unlock social, environmental and economic value

_feedback.correct: That's right.

_incorrect.final: Are you sure?

displayTitle: Are you ready to prioritise your data for publishing?
title: Are you ready to prioritise your data for publishing?

body:
Open data is supporting innovation and growth by revealing opportunities for businesses large and small to build new services, identify savings and improve operations.

In the UK, HulaHub and GetActive enable users to search and compare different activities in their local area.

In Paris, café owners are using open data to attract tourists to the city's most affordable coffees, while, in Iceland, farmers are using open data about the quality of their lambs to attract new customers.

Open data stimulates innovation by removing barriers to access, use and shareability of data.

Data literacy is a core skill for businesses looking to take advantage of the opportunities open data offers to create new value and improve operations.
title: Innovation and growth in businesses

displayTitle: Are you ready to create impact for your organisation from open data?
title: Are you ready to create impact for your organisation from open data?

body:
Open data has the power to help grow economies, transform societies and increase efficiency.

Physical activity providers can use open data to get more people involved, create better experiences for participants and create new products and services that will help more people get active. 

Ready to get hands on? In the next module we explore how to prioritise which data to publish.
title: Ready to create impact?

body:
Physical activity providers can use open data to get more people involved, create better experiences for participants and run their organisations more efficiently. 

In this module, we explore how the public sector, businesses and individuals are using open data to create impact.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • Opportunities for the public sector 
  • Innovation and growth in business
  • Changing society
title: Creating impact from open data

displayTitle: Are you ready to create impact from open data?
title: Are you ready to create impact from open data?

body: Any physical activity dataset can be made open provided it does not contain personal details or sensitive information.  Your organisation needs to prioritise data that will make the greatest impact both for your organisation and for potential users, because data takes time to clean, publish and promote.
displayTitle: Choosing the right data to publish
title: Choosing the right data to publish

body: There are three technical considerations as part of the standards for publishing open data, one of which is...
title: Technical considerations

_items.text: whether it can it be used on a computer
whether it takes up much bandwidth
what format the open data is published in

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data. The format in which the data is published in, the structure of the data and the channels through which the data is available.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data. The format in which the data is published in, the structure of the data and the channels through which the data is available.

displayTitle: Are you ready to ensure quality open data?
title: Are you ready to ensure quality open data?

body: Open data awareness is no longer a luxury for public servants, it is now...
title: Opportunities for the public sector

_items.text: a little more important than it used to be
something that should be researched more
a crucial part of modern service delivery

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

A new generation of voters across the world have grown to expect a digitally literate and engaged public sector.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

A new generation of voters across the world have grown to expect a digitally literate and engaged public sector.

body: Which of the following are errors in data that require cleaning?
title: Improving quality
instruction: Choose three answers and click Submit

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

Mixed use of scales, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed in unclean data. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being unclean.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Mixed use of scales, redundant data and multiple representations of the same data are just some of the errors that need to be fixed in unclean data. While the granularity and lack of licence are a problem, they are not related to the data itself being unclean.

body:
To enjoy these benefits, users need to trust that the data is of good enough quality and they need to be able to use it.

Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it and a machine can manipulate it.

Both of these require the permission of the publisher, granted via an open licence. However, the open licence alone is not sufficient to guarantee the usability of data. Simply putting a file on a website with an open licence does not constitute open data.

It is unlikely that users will be able to properly engage with unusable data to derive insights and demonstrate benefits.

Be aware that cleaning may take longer than you think. A careful cleaning process will, however, save substantial time in the long-run.
title: Quality open data

body:
Any physical activity dataset can be made open provided it does not contain personal details or sensitive information. Prioritising which data to publish openly first can be overwhelming. Your organisation needs to prioritise data that will make the greatest impact both for your organisation and for your users, because data takes time to clean, publish and promote.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • Where do I start?

  • What is opportunity data?

  • Why is opportunity data a good place to start?
title: Prioritising data to publish openly

body:
Publishing open physical activity data can bring benefits to organisations and individuals.  To enjoy these benefits, users need to trust that the data is of good enough quality and they need to be able to use it.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • What is open data quality?
  • What open data standards make data usable?
  • Marques of quality
  • Improving quality
title: Ensuring quality data

body:
The first thing to think about is what you are trying to achieve. What is your end goal for publishing your data openly?

Next, think about your potential users. What are their goals? How would your data help them to achieve their goals?

The most successful open data publications are where the goals of the data owners and the data users have a shared goal or goals. It's rare that everyone starts out with identical goals, so look for areas where those goals overlap. The more closely aligned the goals are, the more successful the publication tends to be.

The physical activities sector is a great example of where the goal of the providers matches the goal of the users. The providers want more people to get active through using their services, and the users want to find activities easily and simply.
title: Where do I start?

body: Opportunity data should be a priority to publish openly, because...
displayTitle: Why is opportunity data a good place to start?
title: Why is opportunity data a good place to start?

_items.text: It will help more get people active
It is a highly economically valuable type of data
Providers will have access to all participantsâ€™ personal data

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Opportunity data is a good place to start when publishing open data, because it helps to meet the shared goal of getting more people active.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Opportunity data is a good place to start when publishing open data, because it helps to meet the shared goal of getting more people active.

body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share. Governments, businesses and individuals can use open data to bring about social, economic and environmental benefits.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • What is open data?
  • What is data?
  • What makes data open?
  • Why does the physical activity sector need open data?
displayTitle: What is open data and how can it help the physical activity sector?
title: What is open data and how can it help the physical activity sector?

body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data becomes usable when made available in a common, machine-readable format.

Open data must be licensed. Its licence must permit people to use the data in any way they want, including transforming, combining and sharing it with others, even commercially.
title: What is open data?

body: Without data we can’t build information, and without information there is no new knowledge.
displayTitle: From raw material to new information and knowledge
title: From raw material to new information and knowledge
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Data
_items.body:
Data is the raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

Think of data as those locations, images, descriptions, reviews and prices that form the basis of information that can help you plan a holiday, for example.

_items.title: Information
_items.body:
Data becomes information when it is given a context.

Following on from the previous example, locations, images, descriptions and prices can all help provide information related to a tourist attraction.

The collection and presentation of data helps to form information.

_items.title: Knowledge
_items.body:
Knowledge is what is derived from information, and personalised for your needs.

Building knowledge is a process of turning information into choices.

Building on the previous example, knowing that no one in your family likes theme parks will help you to decide which places to avoid on holiday, and which would suit your family better.

body:
Data is open if anyone can access, use and share it.
There are some simple things to consider when defining openness:
title: What makes data open?

_items.title: Limitations
_items.body:
For data to be open, it should have no limitations that prevent it from being used in any particular way

Anyone should be free to use, modify, combine and share the data, even commercially

_items.title: Cost
_items.body:
Open data must be free to use, but this does not mean that it must be free to access.

There is often a cost to creating, maintaining and publishing usable data.

Ideally, any fee for accessing open data should be no more than the reasonable reproduction cost of the unit of data that is requested.

This reproduction cost tends to be negligible for many datasets.

Live data and big data can incur ongoing costs related to reliable service provision.

_items.title: Reuse
_items.body:
Once the user has the data, they are free to use, reuse and redistribute it – even commercially.

Open data is measured by what it can be used for, not by how it is made available.

Aspects like format, structure and machine readability all make data more usable, and should all be carefully considered.

However, these do not make the data more open.

body: Open data is...
title: What is open data?

_items.text: information that we sell to businesses
data that anyone can access, use and share
data that is visible on the Web

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data must also be licensed to allow free usage and be available for commercial use.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data must also be licensed to allow free usage and be available for commercial use.

body: Data is...
title: What is data?

_items.text: the raw material of information and knowledge.

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Data is the lowest level of raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Data is the lowest level of raw material from which information and knowledge can be derived.

body: Open data should be...
title: What makes data open?

_items.text: free from restrictions for its use

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

If something restricts the free use of the data, such as a non-commercial restriction, then this would not qualify as being open data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

If something restricts the free use of the data, such as a non-commercial restriction, then this would not qualify as being open data.

body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

Open data is a raw material for the digital age but, unlike coal, timber or diamonds, it can be used by anyone and everyone at the same time.

Any restrictions imposed on the use of open data will limit its potential for creating new value.

Open data can bring diverse benefits to the physical activity sector. It has the power to help improve services, grow participation and create a healthier population.

Ready to make a difference? In the next module, we will explore ways that open data creates impact.
displayTitle: Open data in the physical activity sector
title: Open data in the physical activity sector

body: Any physical activity dataset can be made open provided it does not contain personal details or sensitive information.  Your organisation needs to prioritise data that will make the greatest impact both for your organisation and for potential users, because data takes time to clean, publish and promote.

title: Choosing the right data to publish

body: When planning an open data initiative, consider the following before you start to publish data:
displayTitle: Start with understanding supply and demand
title: Start with understanding supply and demand
instruction: Click the headings to explore further

_items.title: Your approach
_items.body:
Many open data publishers have taken the approach of building a portal, publishing the data they have, and hoping it is what consumers want or need.

As open data literacy grows, people are starting to think first about the needs of data consumers and shape their initiatives accordingly.

A staged approach helps to ensure that your organisation can walk before it tries to run, and achieves change in small, noticeable steps, rather than setting ambitious goals that are hard to meet.

_items.title: Who wants your data?
_items.body:
Open data is an enabler of innovation.

But there is little point in publishing open data if there is no one prepared or motivated to create new value from it.

It is often best to focus on demand that currently exists.

Use existing consumer dialogues, opinion surveys and focus groups to see where the demand is, and follow it.

Think about problems that already exist and how your data relates to them. Offer your data as a tool to help build solutions.

_items.title: Who will use and support your data?
_items.body:
A successful open data initiative has an engaged community who actively use the data, with access to resources that support them.

A strong community of open data reusers has a sense of ownership over the data. This ownership should cover both the data and the outputs generated from it.

It is important for publishers and consumers to fully understand each others’ perspectives.

A good example of a strong open data community is the Open Street Map project.
Take me to the Open Street Map project

_items.title: Assess the value
_items.body:
Value measures how much benefit your organisation and the potential users would get from publishing a particular dataset.

The longer the list of expected benefits to you and to the data users, the higher the value of that dataset. Some datasets will have a high value if publishing them can create lots of different benefits. Others will have little value because they would only benefit a few people.

_items.title: Understand the risk
_items.body:
Risk measures how sensitive the publication of this dataset is. The higher the risk of the dataset, the greater the likelihood that publishing it could have a negative impact on your organisation or on some users.

Most assets will be low risk as sharing them will not jeopardise sensitive organisational details or bring undue scrutiny on users. A few will be more risky because they might expose personal information about employees or participants.

_items.title: Map your datasets
_items.body:
Use the matrix to the right of this box to plot your datasets using the measures of value and risk.

Place a point for each dataset in the correct section of the matrix and label it clearly.

_items.title: List them in order
_items.body:
Once your datasets are mapped to the matrix, rank them in the order of publication. Start with those in the top-right quadrant (the no-brainers). Follow these with the top-left (no-hurries) then bottom-right (no-hopers_ and finally bottom-left (no-chancers).

Start your release with the no-brainers as these combine low risk with high value.

body: Open data becomes usable when...
title: What makes open data quality?

_items.text: it is imported into a common system
a human can understand it, machines can manipulate it and it has an open licence

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it, machines can manipulate it and it is made available under an open licence.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it, machines can manipulate it and it is made available under an open licence.

body:
Datasets need to be easy to understand and use. Whether for a developer to create a new app, a community sports club to deliver better events or for journalists and citizens to hold service providers to account.

Publishing good quality data is one key to encouraging re-use. Improving the quality of your data starts before you publish, by cleaning up entries and correctly formatting data.  You can also increase quality by making data easier for people to find. Finally, through links and promotion, you can generate a larger audience.
title: Why does data quality matter?

body:
Errors and inconsistencies often occur in data.  Common errors include incorrect content, duplicate entries, missing data, inconsistent use of abbreviations, spelling mistakes and different data formats. 

To deal with messy data we recommend OpenRefine, which can help you quickly clean large datasets. Unlike Excel and other spreadsheet programmes, OpenRefine allows you to record the changes you make and can automatically apply cleaning functions to other datasets. 

To get started with OpenRefine, follow our exercise here.
displayTitle: How to improve the quality of the data you publish
title: How to improve the quality of the data you publish

body:
Physical activity providers can use open data to get more people involved, create better experiences for participants and run their organisations more efficiently.   An open data strategy is required to ensure impact is achieved.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • How value is created from publishing open data
  • What a data strategy is
  • Why a data strategy matters
  • The components of a data strategy
displayTitle: How do I create impact for my organisation from open data?
title: How do I create impact for my organisation from open data?

body: Data strategy is composed of 5 key elements. Each of these are essential to delivering the value the organisation wants to derive from their data.
title: Components of data strategy

_items.title: Map
_items.body:
The first key element of data strategy is a comprehensive asset map of who holds and maintains your data.

You need to develop a complete list of the data types your organisation holds & has access to.

For each dataset list an owner, how the data can be accessed and where it is held.

Other useful information includes update frequency and format

_items.title: Describe
_items.body:
The second key component is a good description of each of the data types you hold, access or use.

You need to ensure that all data is described in a uniform, meaningful way that can be easily searched

Each dataset should have a set of common IDs such as name, topic, temporal coverage, ownership, use requirements, format & permissions

This information should be stored in a commonly accessible database pushed at least company-wide

_items.title: Share
_items.body:
The third key component is a plan for how data will be shared both within the organisation and more broadly with partners or the public.

Once data is mapped and described, you need to fix the appropriate access requirements to balance security with ease of use.

Use the data spectrum to select the optimal sharing level for each dataset then consider how to provide it.

Take account of information security throughout.

_items.title: Maintain
_items.body:
The fourth key element of the data strategy is a process for timely and thorough maintenance of the organisation's data assets

Data needs common maintenance. You should put in place expected standards of data quality, educate staff on how to implement them and regularly review.

Staff will often need new skills to maintain data correctly. Place an important emphasis on L&D whether through on-job training, courses or instruction.

Ensure standards are met and maintained through reward

_items.title: Govern
_items.body:
The final key element of the data strategy is a governance plan that ensures leadership and management are equipped to uphold data standards across the organisation.

Ensure that all levels of the organisation have data strategy baked into their work. Appropriate oversight and check-ins will drive adoption and are critical to the process.

Managers need data governance metrics and a person should be appointed as the reviewer of data quality and management.

Govern effectively and ensure everyone understands the vision and the purpose

body: Open data should be...
displayTitle: Which of these is a way that new products and services can be built using open data?
title: Which of these is a way that new products and services can be built using open data?

_items.text: By making an organisation more transparent
By creating a place for developers to share code openly
By enabling developers to create new apps

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Developers can use open data to create new apps

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Developers can use open data to create new apps

body:
Open data is data that anyone can access, use and share.

When data is published openly it becomes a valuable resource for both the organisation that publishes the data and for people that interact with and use the data.  This value comes from new services and products built using the data.  Value is also created by improving the efficiency and performance of organisations and sectors that publish data openly.
displayTitle: How is value created from open data?
title: How is value created from open data?

body: Open data allows a variety of people to develop new things that benefit an organisation and the people it interacts with.
displayTitle: How are new products and services built using open data?
title: How are new products and services built using open data?
instruction: Click the forward arrow to find out how it works
mobileInstruction: Click the arrow to learn more

_items.title: Developers of apps and services
_items.body:
The examples of Transport for London and the travel sector show that often the best app and service developers don't work within organisations that generate data.

By publishing data openly an organisation benefits from the talents of a wider variety of people outside their traditional business.  

In the physical activity sector these people can create tools that give participants a better experience, raise awareness and ultimately get more people involved.

_items.title: Open innovation events
_items.body:
Releasing open data allows organisations to stimulate innovation by organising an event or series of events that seek to address a specific challenge.  There are four main types of open innovation events.

Challenges take place over a few months and are focused on refining problems, helping teams develop ideas into services, and driving real benefits.  An example of this approach is the Open Data Challenge Series which created a 10 to 1 return on investment. Take me to PWC's Open Data Challenge Series Report

Hackathons are events in which computer programmers and others involved in software development collaborate intensively on software projects.  Read about an example from The University of Pennsylvania's PennApps hackathons.

Ideathons are virtual or face-to-face activities designed to generate new ideas in response to a particular user need.  An example of an Ideathon is the The Knight Foundation News Challenges

Datathons are high energy events where mission-driven organizations work alongside teams of volunteer data scientists, developers, and designers to use data to gain new insights or make data more useful.

Find out more about Datathons on the DataKind website

_items.title: Development led by you
_items.body:
Your organisation may be best placed and have the skills needed to create new products and services that will improve participation.

Open data will also provide the basis for collaboration across an organisation and your sector.  This will enable you to work with others on solutions that can be used in a variety of settings.

Your organisation may also choose to work with external specialists to help design and build new things.

body: You strategy describes how you plan to use open data to achieve your organisation's vision. Like any strategy, it begins with the goal or vision of the organisation and the value you wish to create.  It then sets out guiding principles to achieve these results.
displayTitle: How do I develop a strategy for creating value from open data?
title: How do I develop a strategy for creating value from open data?

_items.title: Start with your data
_items.body: Data strategy is primarily focussed on the data your organisation holds itself. This could be everything from locations to events, from clubs to funding.

_items.title: Define the value of data
_items.body: Your strategy then explains how your organisation believes data should add value to your activities and to participants. These beliefs can be very simple (e.g. data will make it easy for people to find activities and events near where they live) or more complex (e.g. data will allow us to continuously monitor the efficiency of our operations and optimise in real time).

_items.title: Your plan of action
_items.body: Your strategy will then set out a plan of action for achieving the value set out in the statements. This plan is used to inform the decisions managers make about how to work so must be clear, achievable and have an obvious benefit for your organisation.

_items.title: Resources
_items.body:
Your strategy will need to identify the people and resources needed to deliver specific elements of the plan.  

For your open data project your plan will typically need to involve legal teams, technical teams, client facing teams and senior leaders.

Resources you may need might include the technical tools required to prepare and publish data.

_items.title: Monitoring and Evaluation
_items.body:
A good strategic plan will include ways to monitor progress and evaluate performance.  

Your organisation should choose goals that the strategy can reasonably impact.  It should break down longer term goals into metrics and indicators that can be measured and monitored.

Timelines and methods of reporting should also be agreed.

body: Data is...
displayTitle: Which of these is a way that open data can create value for your organisation?
title: Which of these is a way that open data can create value for your organisation?

_items.text: It makes your data more secure
It enables the development of new apps
It allows anyone to access and use your website

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Publishing open data will allow developers to create apps that get more people engaged with the activities and events you offer.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Publishing open data will allow developers to create apps that get more people engaged with the activities and events you offer.

body: Open data is...
displayTitle: What are the five components of a data strategy?
title: What are the five components of a data strategy?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Your open data strategy should map the data you have, describe the types you hold and use, plan for how you will share data, describe process for maintaining data assets, and explain how data standards and quality are governed.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The open data strategy components are map, describe, share, maintain and govern.

You will need to map the data you have, describe the types you hold and use, plan for how you will share data, describe process for maintaining data assets, and explain how data standards and quality are governed.

_items.title: Open data develops the skills of your workforce
_items.body:
Data, not just open data, is now a core aspect of many people’s jobs. However, not everyone has the skills required to manage, clean and interpret data.

Open data creates opportunities to increase the level of data literacy in the workforce by raising public awareness of data skills.

_items.title: Open data lets your business innovate
_items.body:
Open data is a key enabler of open innovation.

Opening data can encourage people within an organisation to communicate with each other and with external groups.

Plume Labs, a French startup, combined open data on air quality with advanced monitoring and visualisations to provide the latest air pollution indicators for 18 European cities

Take me to Plume Labs

_items.title: Open data boosts your business
_items.body:
For businesses, opening data can improve relationships with consumers and open up new customer channels.

Thomson Reuters has opened up its identifiers data to make the data it holds discoverable, easy to access and use.

Take me to Thomson Reuters site

_items.title: Open data changes the discussion around physical activity
_items.body:
Open data has the ability to bring about change within societies.

For example, the Swiss government found that opening up their transport safety data gave people greater clarity around accidents. The mapping of this information gives people a more interactive way to engage with the data.

Take me to the Swiss crash map

_items.title: Open data supports the community
_items.body:
Open data helps communities to communicate with each other.

mySociety created FixMyStreet, which allows residents to share problems with their local area as open data and create shared solutions.

Take me to FixMyStreet programme

body:
Across the physical activity sector a key blocker to participation is helping people understand what opportunities exist to get involved.  This kind of data is know as opportunity data.  This data can be turned into useful information for participants to help them easily select sessions, event and activities that meet their goals.  

Publishing opportunity data as open data will help potential participants get active.  For example the data could be used by apps that help people book activity in the same way they book travel.
displayTitle: Why might opportunity data be the best place to start?
title: Why might opportunity data be the best place to start?

body: Data included in opportunity dataset will typically include all the information a participant will need to find, book and attend activities or events that meet their goals.
title: What does opportunity data include?

_items.title: Location
_items.body: Where the activity or provider is based.

_items.title: Time and date
_items.body: Either over a broad range (e.g. this weekend), or a specific time (e.g. 6pm tonight).

_items.title: Contact details
_items.body: Ways for people to get in touch with organisers.  This might include an email address, phone number and website.

_items.title: Activity type
_items.body: What kind of activity is this?  For example yoga, hockey or fencing.

_items.title: Experience or skills level
_items.body: Is the activity, session or event targeted at beginners or people with more experience?

_items.title: Defined participant types
_items.body: Such as age group, accessibility, and gender.

_items.title: Tags
_items.body: A broader set of options e.g. relaxing, fun, social.

_items.title: Costs
_items.body: Whether it is free, requires membership or a one off payment.

_items.title: Mandatory Participation Requirements
_items.body: Such as participant supplied safety equipment or accreditation.

body:
Publishing open data can bring benefits to any organisation in the physical activity sector.   For these benefits to be realised users need to be able to find the data.  They need to understand what it can (and can't) be used for.  They need the data to be of a the right level of quality and in a format that makes it useable. 

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • What makes data usable?
  • How standards help increase the usability of data
  • Marques of quality
  • Why does data quality matter?
  • How to improve the quality of data you publish
  • Where should you publish your data?
  • How can you make data easier to find?
displayTitle: How is physical activity data accessed, used and shared?
title: How is physical activity data accessed, used and shared?

body: Community-driven standards define the legal, practical, technical and social requirements for an open dataset to be useful.
displayTitle: What standards should I stick to?
title: What standards should I stick to?
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Legal requirements
_items.body:
Legal requirements

In addition to the open licence, there are three legal requirements that need to be considered. You must:

  • Protect sensitive information like personal data.
  • Preserve the rights of data owners.
  • Promote correct use of the data.

_items.title: Practical requirements
_items.body:
It is important that open data can be found and relied upon by users.

This means that open data publishers must:

  • Link to the data from their website.
  • Update the data regularly if it changes.
  • Commit to continue to make the data available.

_items.title: Social requirements
_items.body:
For data use to be sustainable, it is important to have an engaged community of users. The best datasets have:

  • Active support channels.
  • Discussion groups and forums.
  • Published how-to guides on working with the data.

_items.title: Technical requirements
_items.body:
There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data:

  • The format in which the data is published.
  • The structure of the data.
  • The channels through which the data is available.

body:
Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it and a machine can manipulate it.

Users of open data need the permission of its publisher, granted by an open licence. But the open licence alone is not enough to guarantee the usability of data.

It is difficult for people to engage with data to derive insights and demonstrate benefits if it's hard to use.
title: What is open data quality?

body: Marques of quality provide users with confidence about the quality and usability of open data.  There are two key indicators of open data quality:
title: Marques of quality

_items.title: 5 stars
_items.body:
The '5 Stars of linked open data' include the basic legal definition and technical excellence of the published data.

The 5 Stars were developed by inventor of the Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee, in 2001. The 5 Stars make recommendations for the format and structure of the data.

_items.title: ODI Open data certificates
_items.body:
The Open Data Institute's Open Data Certificates are practical, social, legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing or using open data.

The certificates act as a self-assessment questionnaire for publishers, and in some cases users, to assess and benchmark the full usability of a dataset.  Take me to the ODI Open Data Certificates site

body: In England, 57% of adults do not play sport. A 'lack of information on what's available' is one of a number of factors that prevent people from exercising enough. Publishing data openly will get more people active.
displayTitle: Why does the physical activity sector need open data?
title: Why does the physical activity sector need open data?

_items.title: Improving the users' experience
_items.body:
Enabling people to easily find and book activities will help increase participation.  

By publishing data openly, providers will make it easier for websites and apps to reuse and share data, and create information that people can act on.

This will improve user satisfaction and ultimately create a better experience for participants.

_items.title: Creating innovation in the sector
_items.body: Open data is driving a new wave of innovative apps, websites and products.  By publishing data openly providers and national bodies can help stimulate the development of new ideas and ways for getting people active.

body:
To understand the impact of the data you plan to publish, you need to take a demand-focused approach. A demand-focussed approach examines what benefits the users of your data will get from it. When you consider how users will benefit from your data, you can better understand which data has the greatest potential impact and prioritise publishing it.  You can also understand what features of the data make it useable by others.

Below are some of the benefits users may get from physical activity open data:
displayTitle: How can I understand how what I publish might make an impact?
title: How can I understand how what I publish might make an impact?

body:
Deciding which data to publish requires trade-offs. Data takes time to clean up, prepare and make available, so you cant open everything at once. In addition some datasets, like those containing personal details of participants, should not be made open. To decide where to focus your efforts, you need to weigh up the benefits and risks of publishing different types of data and then make a decision.

Your decision about which data to publish is ultimately based on the unique situation of your organisation. However, certain things are universal no matter who you are:
displayTitle: How do I decide what data to publish?
title: How do I decide what data to publish?

displayTitle: Are you ready to prioritise your data for publication?
title: Are you ready to prioritise your data for publication?

displayTitle: Are you ready to publish data in the right way?
title: Are you ready to publish data in the right way?

body: Publishing open data can bring benefits to any organisation in the physical activity sector. For these benefits to be realised users need to be able to find the data.  They need to understand what it can (and can't) be used for.  They need the data to be of a the right level of quality and in a format that makes it useable.
displayTitle: Publishing physical activity data the right way!
title: Publishing physical activity data the right way!

body: The Open Data Institute advocates the use of its own quality marque known as...
title: Symbols of quality

_feedback.correct:
That's right!

The Open Data Institute has developed Open Data Certificates which include practical and social requirements alongside in-depth legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing open data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

The Open Data Institute has developed Open Data Certificates which include practical and social requirements alongside in-depth legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing open data.

body:
Any physical activity dataset can be made open provided it does not contain personal details or sensitive information.  Your organisation needs to prioritise data that will make the greatest impact both for your organisation and for potential users, because data takes time to clean, publish and promote.

In this module we’ll explore the following:

  • Supply and Demand for open data
  • How can I prioritise what data to publish?
  • Who can help me with deciding what to publish?
  • Why is opportunity data the best starting point for publishing open data?
displayTitle: How do I decide what data to publish?
title: How do I decide what data to publish?

displayTitle: Are you ready for open physical activity data?
title: Are you ready for open physical activity data?

body:
Physical activity providers can use open data to get more people involved, create better experiences for participants and run their organisations more efficiently.   An open data strategy is required to ensure impact is achieved.

In this module we have explored the following:

  • How value is created from publishing open data
  • What a data strategy is
  • Why a data strategy matters
  • The components of a data strategy
displayTitle: How do I create impact for my organisation from physical activity data?
title: How do I create impact for my organisation from physical activity data?

body: There are three technical considerations as part of the standards for publishing open data, one of which is...
title: Technical considerations

_items.text: whether it can it be used on a computer
whether it takes up much bandwidth
what format the open data is published in

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data. The format in which the data is published in, the structure of the data and the channels through which the data is available.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data. The format in which the data is published in, the structure of the data and the channels through which the data is available.

body: Open data is unlocking new social value and enabling data-driven decisions across a wide range of sectors. In the physical activities sector, this means getting more people active.
title: Changing society
instruction: Click the headings to explore further.

_items.title: Meeting digital expectations
_items.body:
Many opportunities to do physical activity are hidden away in old old-fashioned websites, social media groups, PDFs or printed flyers.

Publishing this data openly in a standardised format enables consumers to easily discover what activities are available to them.

_items.title: Improving health and wellbeing
_items.body:
The link between physical activity and physical and mental health is well established.

Tools such as Grace - an AI messaging platform to help you with your mental wellbeing  - are built on open data.

body: Examples of opportunity data are...
title: What is opportunity data?

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Location, activity and cost are all examples of opportunity data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Location, activity and cost are all examples of opportunity data.

body: A good place to start when prioritising which data to publish openly is by...
title: Where do I start?

_items.text: Identifying the shared goals of the data provider and the data user

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

If something restricts the free use of the data, such as a non-commercial restriction, then this would not qualify as being open data.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

If something restricts the free use of the data, such as a non-commercial restriction, then this would not qualify as being open data.

body: Open data becomes usable when...
title: What makes open data quality?

_items.text: it is imported into a common system
a human can understand it, machines can manipulate it and it has an open licence

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it, machines can manipulate it and it is made available under an open licence.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure about that?

Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it, machines can manipulate it and it is made available under an open licence.

body:
Open data becomes usable when a human can understand it and a machine can manipulate it.

Users of open data need the permission of its publisher, granted by an open licence. But the open licence alone is not enough to guarantee the usability of data.

It is hard for people to engage with data to derive insights and demonstrate benefits if the data is difficult to use.
title: What is open data quality?

body:
Errors and inconsistencies often occur in data.  Common errors include duplicate entries, missing data, inconsistent use of abbreviations, spelling mistakes, mixed numerical scales and ranges and different data formats. 

To deal with messy data we recommend OpenRefine, which can help you quickly clean large datasets. Unlike Excel and other spreadsheet programmes, OpenRefine allows you to record the changes you make and can automatically apply cleaning functions to other datasets. 

To get started with OpenRefine, follow our exercise here.
title: Improving quality

_items.title: 5 stars

The '5 Stars of linked open data' include the basic legal definition and technical excellence of the published data.

The 5 Stars were developed by inventor of the Web, Sir Tim Berners-Lee, in 2001. The 5 Stars make recommendations for the format and structure of the data.

_items.title: ODI Open data certificates
_items.body:
The Open Data Institute's Open Data Certificates are practical, social, legal and technical guidelines to consider when publishing or using open data.

The certificates act as a self-assessment questionnaire for publishers, and in some cases users, to assess and benchmark the full usability of a dataset.  Take me to the ODI Open Data Certificates site

body: The public sector benefits from open data initiatives in many ways:
title: Opportunities for the public sector
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Supporting growing economies
_items.body:
To support the emergence of new data-driven businesses and the growth of existing ones, the public sector needs to publish key datasets.

The public sector s also needs to support data infrastructure that connects data with those who use it.

In return, the public sector is reaping the benefits of a growing data economy, such as in Finland where SMEs with access to open data grew 15% faster than those without.

Take me to the Finnish case study

_items.title: Improved service delivery
_items.body:
The availability of detailed open data is essential to improving delivery of services for businesses and individuals.

In the physical activities sector, British Cycling publishes data on Sky Ride events so that more users are aware when and where the Sky Rides are taking place.

In the transport sector, Transport for London, released their travel data and enabled developers to provide consumer-friendly services, providing customers with an estimated £58 million per year in saved time.

_items.title: Efficiency savings
_items.body:
In the public sector, the Government of South Australia saves $3.2m annually on Freedom of Information requests through proactively releasing data.

Startup Prescribing Analytics – a joint venture between NHS doctors and technologists – used open data to identify a £200m annual saving for the NHS if they were to switch to own-brand statins and utilise more efficient delivery routes.

body: Open data is driving innovation and growth by...
title: Innovation and growth in business

_items.text: being made available on the Web
motivating innovators to use public sector data
revealing opportunities to build new services and improve operations

_feedback.correct:
That’s right!

Data literacy is a core skill for businesses looking to take advantage of the opportunities open data offers to create new value and improve operations.

_incorrect.final:
Are you sure?

Data literacy is a core skill for businesses looking to take advantage of the opportunities open data offers to create new value and improve operations.

body: Community-driven standards define the legal, practical, technical and social requirements for an open dataset to be useful.
displayTitle: What open data standards make data usable?
title: What open data standards make data usable?
instruction: Click the forward arrow to see more.

_items.title: Legal requirements
_items.body:
Legal requirements

In addition to the open licence, there are three legal requirements that need to be considered. You must:

  • Protect sensitive information like personal data.
  • Preserve the rights of data owners.
  • Promote correct use of the data.

_items.title: Practical requirements
_items.body:
It is important that open data can be found and relied upon by users.

This means that open data publishers must:

  • Link to the data from their website.
  • Update the data regularly if it changes.
  • Commit to continue to make the data available.

_items.title: Technical requirements
_items.body:
There are three recommendations that define the technical aspects of open data:

  • The format in which the data is published.
  • The structure of the data.
  • The channels through which the data is available.

_items.title: Social requirements
_items.body:
For data use to be sustainable, it is important to have an engaged community of users. The best datasets have:

  • Active support channels.
  • Discussion groups and forums.
  • Published how-to guides on working with the data.

body:
Across the physical activity sector a key blocker to participation is helping people understand what is available.  This kind of data is known as opportunity data.  

Opportunity data is data tells someone who wants to do an activity when and where that activity is happening.

The headings below explore different data that you might find in an opportunity dataset.
title: What is opportunity data?
instruction: Click on the headings to explore further

_items.title: What it is
_items.body: What kind of activity is this? For example, yoga, hockey or fencing.

_items.title: Where it is
_items.body: The location where the activity takes place or where the provider is based.

_items.title: When it is
_items.body: The time and date when the activity would take place. This could be over a broad range (e.g. this weekend), or a specific time (e.g. 6pm on Wednesday).

_items.title: Who it's for
_items.body: Is the activity, session or event suitable for beginners or targeted at people with more experience? Are there restrictions, such as age group, accessibility, or gender?

_items.title: How much
_items.body: Is the activity free, does it require membership or can I make a one-off payment?

_items.title: How to get in contact
_items.body: Ways for people to get in contact with organisers. This might include an email address, phone number and website.

_items.title: Requirements
_items.body: Do I need to wear something specific or bring any safety equipment? Do I need to have a qualification to do this activity?

body:
In the physical activities sector, publishing opportunity data as open data will help achieve the shared goal of getting more people active. 

Open opportunity data can be turned into useful information and enable participants to easily find and book activities that match their needs.

It can drive competition between providers and improve their services, as participants have a better understanding of what activities are available. 

Open opportunity data can also enable innovation in the sector as new businesses and providers identify gaps in the market.
displayTitle: Why is opportunityÂ data a good place to start?
title: Why is opportunityÂ data a good place to start?

title: Changing society

_items.text: It improves access to different sports
It increases the number of sports centres

_incorrect.final:
